Award.AwardTitle: Cognitive Rhythms Collaborative: A Discovery Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports the Collaborative Rhythms Collaborative (CRC), a group of scientists in the Boston area who have begun to work together to advance our understanding of the brain dynamics underlying cognitive functions such as attention, sensation, motor planning, and memory. There is a growing consensus that dynamics are central to understanding how the brain works, but major gaps exist in what we know and in how we seek to understand more. The CRC has focused on the dynamical regime most strongly associated with cognition, rhythmic activity in the frequency range 1 - 200 Hz. Its central aims are to characterize the physiological origins and functions of such rhythms and to understand how pathologies in rhythmic dynamics are related to symptoms and mechanisms of neurological disease. Mathematical modeling, cutting-edge statistical techniques, and their implementation as computer algorithms will be critical to carrying out its scientific program. The grant will support the CRC, concentrating on the application of the mathematical sciences to the investigation of brain dynamics and the potential for new mathematical, statistical and computational techniques driven by challenging scientific problems. This will include support of a technology core that will create new hardware/software platforms to support such techniques. The CRC will also provide mentoring and teaching to a large community of students and post-doctoral fellows.

The Cognitive Rhythms Collaborative, involving multiple institutions in the Boston area, offers a unique chance to develop a network of researchers from the mathematical, biological, and cognitive sciences to explore fascinating questions in the area of neuroscience. This is a different mechanism of interaction than is traditionally seen and has the potential to transform the way such interdisciplinary problems are addressed. The CRC seeks to provide new ways of doing science by fostering broader and deeper collaboration in addressing scientific questions. This work will involve tight collaborations among scientists with a multitude of backgrounds, and will emphasize the role of mathematics in the investigation of neuroscience questions. The CRC will also train a cohort of postdoctoral fellows in a way that will lead to a deep understanding of the intellectual context of their work. The technology core of the project will produce both hardware and software that will be available within and beyond the CRC, and enable computations that are now almost impossible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cognitive Rhythms Collaborative is designed to facilitate collaboration among researchers, including students and postdoctoral associates, who are working on brain dynamics.  The group has expertise in genetics, technology development, in vivo and in vitro physiology, techniques for human measurements (EEG/MEG/Ecog), neurosurgery, statistics, data analysis and dynamical systems modeling. The senior members are:

Boston University Nancy Kopell*, Uri Eden*, Oded Ghitza*, Xue Han, Mark Kramer*, Howard Eichenbaum, Michael Hasselmo*, Michelle McCarthy*, Kamal Sen*, Jason Ritt*, Barbara Shinn-Cunningham*, Lucia Vaina

MIT  Ann Graybiel, Bob Desimone, Matt Wilson, Ed Boyden, Emery Brown*, Earl Miller, Li-Huei Tsai.

MGH/Harvard Medical School/Martinos Imaging Center   Emery Brown, Steven Stufflebeam, Matti Hämäläinen*, Seppo Ahlfors, Sydney Cash, Patrick Purdon

Mass General Hospital Emad Eskandar

Brandeis  Donald Katz, Robert Sekuler

Tufts   Christoph Borgers*  

Harvard Medical School   Bernat Kocsis,  Daniel Goldin, Kevin Spencer, Ritchie Brown, Robert Stickgold

Mass. Eye and Ear  Daniel Polley 

Brown Christopher Moore, Stephanie Jones*

Newcastle UK  Fiona LeBeau

University of York UK Miles Whittington

* denotes members with significant mathematical or computational research. All students and postdocs associated with these labs are considered members of the CRC, as well as other who request to join.  We have over 270 such members now.  To facilitate its mission, The CRC has had multiple kinds of events:

Working groups:  These are subsets of CRC members (all levels, mostly students and postdocs) who meet to talk about particular subjects within brain dynamics.  Some recent examples of working groups included statistics of data analysis, special properties of certain brain rhythms, physiology measurements, anesthesia, sleep, and optimal coding. 

Dinner Lectures: CBD hosts 2-4 dinner lectures a year at MIT, paid for by MIT’s McGovern Institute.  The lecture/conversations are about two hours, given by CRC or outside faculty, and involve intense interaction between the audience and the speaker.  The lectures generally attaract 35-60 attendees.

Retreat: Each year, the CRC hold an all-day event with about 10 student/postdoc speakers and a senior outside major speaker.   Also provided are a lunch and a reception/poster session. The retreat attracts 90-100 people a year, including representatives from the local pharmaceutical industries.

Mini-symposia.  Over this grant, the CRC has 4 minsymposia.  These are one afternoon long, with 4 speakers, a break and a reception.  They generally attract 90-100 people. Titles of the symposia were:  “Brain Rhythms and Active Sensing” (2009),  “Brain Rhythms and Audition” (2011),  “Beta Rhythms and Cognition (2012) and "Frontiers in Non-invasive Brain Stimulation" (2014).

International Conference, in (2013) The CRC held an international conference on Brain Rhythms and Cognition at MIT.  There were over 200 participants, and speakers from 15 institutions and 3 countries.

Workshop: in 2016, the CRC paired with the pharmaceutical company Biogen to host a full-day workshop on Neurophysiology-Based Biomarkers, with a focus on Alzheimers disease and Parkinson’s Disease. 
 
Technology at CRC

“Wired” Project: Under the direction of the Boyden Lab, The CRC developed a high-speed data acquisition system, now published and available for free; it is has become a commercial project sold by Leaflabs.

Autopatching: The Boyden lab developed an image guided version of autopatching that can home in on individual fluorescent cells in the living mouse brain. It automatically compensates for cell movement by tracking cell position and adjusting pipette motion while approaching neurons of multiple types in the living mouse cortex, without human intervention, with yields comparable to skilled human experimenters.

A new platform for shared simulations: DynaSim is a Matlab/Octave toolbox available for free on GitHub created by Jason Sherfey of the Kopell lab for rapid prototyping of large neural models, batch simulation management, and efficient model sharing. It is designed to speed up and simplify the process of generating, sharing, and exploring network models of neurons with a few compartments. It requires no user programming and interfaces a crowd-sourced model database to facilitate model sharing and modular model building.

High dimensional data analysis toolbox: CRC postdoc David Stanley created a MATLAB toolbox called the MultiDimensionalDictionary (MDD). This streamlines many common operations associated with high-dimensional data, such as collapsing dimensions, packing dimensions into matrices for rapid analysis, and sorting/searching data. This toolbox has thus far been used as the backend for multiple CRC projects, including the DynaSim modeling toolbox and GIMBL-Vis visualization toolbox developed by Erik Roberts. This toolbox open source and is available on Github (https://github.com/davestanley/MultiDimensionalDictionary).

Research at the CRC

The researchers at the CRC have produced 169 published papers in CRC related areas.  The major areas include the physiology of multiple brain rhythms, applications to cognition (e.g., attention, active sensing, decision making, sleep, resting state, audition, motor control, olfaction), and applications to diseases such as Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia and autism, epilepsy, as well as anesthesia.  There was also focus on development of cutting-edge tools in the analysis of neural data. Multiple new collaborations were formed involving trainees as well as senior members, across multiple institutions.
